“I can’t shut him up too soon,” the inspector thought. “What if he is the man? I’d lose my chance for evidence.” 

He recalled the siege at Sevastopol. 

“They preferred a regular siege,” he murmured. “Two months of suspense. A man in fear reveals himself.” 

He smiled. 

“Rodion Romanovitch, every case is unique. Let him feel my gaze. Let him suspect.” 

With each moment of terror, the truth would emerge. The inspector was sure of it.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The speaker argues that allowing a suspected criminal to remain in suspense can lead to revealing evidence, as the psychological pressure may drive them to act in ways that confirm their guilt.
